questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: Being able to better organize my projects, to do more advanced functions and prepare for making actual analyses in R.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: Better, efficient and reproductable data management and version control using Git

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: Cleaning and managing data in a systematic way

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: Data cleaning and wrangling with the combination of cross-sectional survey data and longitudinal register data

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: Data handling and getting to know git

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: Further data analysis. For instance would I be able to learn how to code a function directly into a 2x2 table (using knitr?) so I don't have to first calculate the data, and then "manually" put in in the table.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: Get more comfortable with R and open science

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I expect to be able to manage larger projects and handle data in a reproducible manner, utilising FAIR principles.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I expect to build on the things i learned in the introductory course. I would like to be able to do some data processing in a efficient and reproducible way.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I expect to get a more familiar with R and the packages. And to handle raw data.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I expect to learn to clean datasets and work reproducible. I will apply my knowledge in my PhD studies.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I feel rather comfortable doing datamanagement within the tidyverse. But I would like to improve my understanding of the packages and codes that I use and to get better habits and a systematic approach to keeping my code reproducible and readable. So a better coding practice. Begin to create functions.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I hope to be able to better organize projects and feel comfortable with the pipeline of setting up reproducible environments for functions, scripts, data, and documentation.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I hope to develop a better understanding of how to use R, so I can work more independently and confidently. Currently, I rely heavily on ChatGPT for support, and my goal is to become less dependent by strengthening my own skills. I would like to better understand what I am doing when working with R, enabling me to create more reproducible workflows. Additionally, I hope to become more comfortable and secure using RStudio as my main development environment.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I hope to gain insights into the various options in R that I'm not yet familiar with, but that could potentially enhance my work with data.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I want to continue to learn about R and feel more and more confident using it and gain some automatisms by repetition

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I would like to consolidate what I have learnt so far from the beginner course to be able to process and analyze data.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I would like to improve my R skills

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I would like to learn how to process and analyze data. would be nice to also do some tidying and cleaning on datasets.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I would like to learn to process data faster and in a more efficient way. I would also like to learn to have a more organized workflow. I currently use R markdown so individual scripts that I develop are fairly organized. However, I struggle with keeping track of the changed versions and folder organization. Similarly, in my institute, we do have a system of sharing code. However, it is an issue to decipher each other's code, since there is no 'standardized' way of doing this. I would like to learn better ways to share code.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I'm working with data from a human clinical trial. I've performed initial data analysis in Rstudio (mixed model, model check etc) learned from biostatistics courses with little to no reproducibility and/or version control. I hope to learn to manage folders, R files and scripts in a 'reproducible' way and learn good data processing habits early on in my research career. Also, I hope to get to learn a bit more of coding in R in general

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: Import my data, make it tidier, and learn of to make working functions

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: Iâ€™m hoping to learn how to make my data analysis workflows in R more reproducible and easier to share, specially with the people in my group. I work with very complex datasets, so being able to clean and process them efficiently will be really helpful in order to collaborate with my colleagues.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: Learn how to make a reproducible workflow in R

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: To gain insight into how functions work and how to set them up so that it can work on a large variety of datasets.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: To generally learn to code in R, set up my project in Statistics Denmark, and learn do the required data management for starting statistical analyses of my phd studies (I need to join 4-5 datasets in order to conduct study I of my phd)

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: To get more confident in wrangling.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: To make data ready for analysis performed at e.g. statistical courses and to apply the methods learned on own data

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: more capabilities in reproducibility and data processing

questions: What do you expect to learn from this workshop and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: to get more familiar working with R and improve my workflow and make it reproducible.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Everything is nicely explained and detailed enough. Fun!

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Fine

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Good structure and explanation of the basic concepts.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Guidance through the tasks worked well.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Intuitive and well documented

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: It is a fair amount of tasks, and a good idea to make sure everybody that everybody has downloaded the data-set.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: It is a nice step-by-step guide that is easy to follow

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: It is easy to understand what to do, and everything is well explained on the website. The introduction course was also easy to follow and complete without having participated in the workshop.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: It is nicely details

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: It is very clear with the directions

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: It is very nice that it is so step-wise, and that it is explained what all the code chunks does.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: It was really nice to see an overview of all the codes which was used. This helped me to locate where and why I made a mistake.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: It worked well with hands on.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: It works great with the copy paste manual. And the explanation of what result that are to be expected. Backtracking when new is difficult! It works well to have a website you can open repeatedly. When having to do the introduction course as a pretask course activity for us not able to attend one, the small videos made it easier. When you do not know what to expect, an error often causes the arms to fall of :-)

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Knowing expectations and what to prepare is always a better starting point for learning in a course. Lots of nice links to open according to need.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Step-by-step guidance

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: The detailed description on what the programmer is actually setting up and the accompanying documentation links. Also the fact the there is a function for checking the setup.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: The pre-workshop task I liked, as it gets you started. Nice step by step introduction

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: The process is very streamlined

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: The tasks and explanations are very clear

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Things worked well. The instructions were clear and the pictures acted as visual aid.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Very easy to follow in general! The descriptions are very thorough and there is no way to get lost in the process

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Very helpful and easy to follow

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Very thorough descriptions and explanations (even the additional things like automatic synchronisation of files and GDPR vs Open data comment)

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Well written, well structured.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Writing everythjing very explicitly. Making it possible to copy with just the click of a buttom the code.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Yes, absolutely

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: i could get all but one code to run (it was one of the optional once). I think it was well described and it is nice to have all the material online.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: the pre-course material it really well described. Nice that it was adressed for both windows and mac users.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: the step-by-step guide and brush up from the introductory course

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: Adding errors that can occur while doing pre-course task and how to fix them, because I guess you have a lot of experience and know with what we are usually struggling. That will allow us to fix the mistake and learn from it.

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: Currently I have no comments on what should be improved.

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: Easy to just copy the code in the boxes, it saves me a lot of time, but I probably learn less

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: For now nothing

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: Had some troubles with creating a new Git token, but could resolve on my own after a while.

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: Hmmmm.... perhaps already in the invitation email state how long we could expect for the completion of the tasks to take. I didn't know until I read the enitre email and opened the tasks that I would take me 2-6 hours. Thank you.

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: I do not have any suggestions for improvement

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: I hope, you use a little time (5-10 minutes to show us/make time before lessons to a quick guide) on the introduction to git hub - reading about it from the introduction course is not enough for me - I would prefer physical attendance to learn it first time as there was no introduction course for me to attend (started as a phd student in March). However, I feel otherwise equipped to learn the objectives for this course.

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: I think you need to give some tricks and tips to counter the admin issue - I asked ChatGPT to help with that, otherwise I would have been stuck

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: I would like it if there was a guide on how to update R and RStudio (if your version is too old), and on how to update your credentials for github (mine was expired since the introductory course and it caused issues - but i managed to fix it)

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: I've had a few issues not covered by the pre workshop task where I had to use a chatbot to proceed, eg:> dir_delete(here("data-raw/dime"))Error: [ENOENT] Failed to search directory '/Users/au483046/Desktop/LearnR3/data-raw/dime': no such file or directory

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: Installing everything was a bit challenging at first, especially because I hadn't used Git and RStudio before. It was hard to figure out how to download everything correctly, and I found it difficult to follow the predefined tasks in the exact right order.The first time, I used a Windows work computer and managed to get most things to work. However, when I reached the final step where I had to run r3::check_project_setup_intermediate() in the console, I didnâ€™t get any output.I think the issue was related to an earlier problem, because my project folder was located at "~/One-Drive.../Desktop/LearnR3", and since it was a work computer, I couldnâ€™t fix the folder setup properly.Now, I have switched to using my own MacBook, and I find it much easier to complete all the tasks and get everything working as expected.

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: Is there a cheat sheet that you would recommend? Having so many choicesâ€”like those on the Quarto webpageâ€”can be a bit overwhelming."

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: It might have been nicer to have the 'Create the R project' and 'Quarto' sections before the section on 'Git'.

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: It was really clear to me. I encountered some issues with Git credentials, which could be nice to show how to handle.

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: It would be nicer to have more solutions in case we had error

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: Maybe make a note that, depending where we work, we might be able to download RStudio etc... through the "company portal" like it is the case at SDU.

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: Maybe more pre-work for more experienced R-users

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: More explicitly write what "a bit like this" is.. (the last task: the output should look "a bit like this"). In my output, the "README.md" document is missing, as compared to in the pre-workshop notes.

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: No. Good as it is

responses: Nothing

responses: Nothing at the moment

responses: Nothing really

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: There is a small mistake in the survey. It is asking to run r3::check_project_setup() in the survey but this returns an error. > r3::check_project_setup()Fejl: 'check_project_setup' is not an exported object from 'namespace:r3'It should be written as the code in the pre-task> r3::check_project_setup_intermediate()

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: When having to read more about something on another web page. it would be nice if it opened up in a different "fane".

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: When you still a a beginner in R, it somestimes can be difficult to understand all the shortcuts. It is very easy to copy paste, and nice when it works. But It is very good the places, where it is described in words what the code mean or how you also can do it. I sometimes experience that when I need to translate/use the codes into other data sets or in an other setting I come in short handed because I miss the link to understand the shortcuts.

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: nothing really
